article: For almost two months Dominic York, a 23-year-old hairdresser, wandered about hospitals all night, wearing a white coat and pretending he was a doctor. Yesterday he proudly claimed in _ that despite his complete _ of medical experience or qualifications, he had saved several people's lives. He had even been allowed to assist a surgeon during an emergency operation on a patient who was _ to die on something she had swallowed. "I watched one of those TV dramas about a hospital and suddenly I felt like playing one of the roles myself. So I put on a white jacket and a stethoscope and walked around one of the biggest hospitals in London. "At first, I just _ Once you learn how doctors talk to patients, nurses and other doctors, it's easy to _ people in," he said. One of the patients he treated was Laura Kennan. She had been knocked down by a car and fainted. When she arrived "He looked very professional. He told me his name was Doctor Simon. Then he gave me some sort of injection," she said. And then he suddenly cleared off when a nurse asked who he was. She didn't think there was anything wrong. "I would never have _ he was a fake if a policewoman hadn't showed me his _ Judge Raymond Adams told York that he was "shocked and horrified" that he got away with his cheating for so long and then _ him to eighteen months in a special prison for criminals with mental disorders. "I can only hope that this will not lead to _ problems. After all, you will have considerable opportunity to study the _ of the psychiatrists who will look after you while you are there. If you try to persuade people that you yourself are a _ after you are set free, I shall make sure that you are given a much longer sentence." Judge Adams warned York.
